title: Baltinglass Jotter
body_text:
Baltinglass Jotter
REVIEW OF THE YEAR – PART 1
January
Baltinglass Hope for Humanity holds a small impromptu vigil at McAllister on New Year’s Eve, one of many throughout the country, to remember the people of Gaza. Baltinglass Golf Club hold a sponsored walk that raises €1,140 for their juvenile members and homeless charity ‘In Their Shoes’. The St. Patrick’s Day parade committee announce the return of the St. Patrick’s Day parade in 2024 after 4 years without a parade. Winners of the Window Display competition run by Baltinglass Tidy Towns were Slaney Veterinary Centre, Patterson’s Butchers and Daisy a Day. Baltinglass Sings community choir, funded by Creative Places Baltinglass is set to continue and opens to new members. Baltinglass Bulldogs Men’s Basketball Team beat Carlow in a nail-biting match. Former Baltinglass GAA Club player Anthony Nolan is appointed Referee to the AIB GAA Football All-Ireland Junior Club Championship. Rathdangan Drama Group in full rehearsal mode for the upcoming performances in February. Mairead Kelly from Inisfáil social Circle launches her Audio Tour of ‘Ireland’s Hillfort Capital’ in Baltinglass library. Baltinglass Mart hold their 49th Show & Sales over two days for Bullocks, Heifers and Cows. Wicklow Councillor Shay Cullen announces that he will not contest the June local elections. Eleven year old Abi Donohoe from Baltinglass is honoured by autism charity foundation AsIAm for her bravery during a shocking assault of children in Dublin in November 2023 which led to the Dublin riots.
February
The Nationwide Deposit Return scheme gets under way from February 1. Rathdangan Drama Group perform their new play ‘Troubled Bachelors’. Baltinglass Day Care Centre hold a ‘Fill a Bag’ weekend over two weekends. McGreals pharmacy give free CPR training in each of their stores during February. Scoil Naomh Iósaf pupils are successful in Stage One of the Credit Union Quiz in both Junior and Senior competitions. Local musician Mark Caplice presents an evening with Rising Stars featuring three local artists (including Padraig McGrath and Amy Barrett) in Horans funded by Creative Places Baltinglass. Baltinglass Renewal works finally begin in the town. Baltinglass Library put on a free talk by Liz Tiernan on Trees followed by an Ogham art workshop. Bigstone put on their annual Tractor Run to raise funds for the community centre. Kiltegan Tractor Run committee present Baltinglass Hospital with a cheque for €4,000 for their patient comfort fund. Former Vice Principal of Scoil Chonglais, Kevin Browne passes away. The hunt for the Wicklow Rose and Escorts for the Rose of Tralee gets under way. Wicklow TD Jennifer Whitmore visits Tearmann Community Garden describing it as ‘beautifully serene’ and stating she would like to see these in every town in the county.
March
Planning for the Lidl in the town is refused by Wicklow County Council as not efficient use of town centre zoned lands. An artist’s gathering and networking event takes place combined with a Seed Funding Clinic organised by Creative Places Baltinglass. Charlie Bird passes away on March 11, mourned by many nationwide. Rathcoran residents make a presentation during a spring clean-up to Trish Baldwin for her work in keeping the estate so clean. Amira Pender from Baltinglass Badminton Club wins Bronze at the English Gold Star tournament in Edinburgh. The St. Patrick’s Day parade and festivities are a huge success with arts and crafts stalls, face-painting and an outdoor music concert featuring the Ballymore Eustace Concert Band and Neon River amongst others. The Active Retired celebrate their 20th anniversary with a float at the St. Patrick’s Day Parade. Vinny Gethings organises Sitting Room music sessions for the Lalor Centre and Baltinglass Hospital on St. Patrick’s Day, funded by Creative Places Baltinglass. Baltinglass Adult Education Centre teach participants to sew. Men’s Shed celebrate their 10th anniversary, originally founded in March 2014. The Traffic For Ireland (TFI) Local Link bus service extends to six daily return services from Monday to Friday and 4 return services on Saturday and Sunday. The Kiltegan Order is shocked by the shooting of one of their own, Fr. William Banda SPS, in the sacristy of the Holy Trinity Cathedral in Tzaneen, South Africa as he prepared to say Mass. West Wicklow Historical Society receive record attendance at their talk by John O’Brien on ‘The Station Masters and Employees of the Sallins-Tullow Railway Line’. Chairman Paul Gorry announces the society’s new honorary member, Aidan Cruise from Kilbride. The Kearney family experience the tragic loss of two family members on the same day, Margaret and Eoin Kearney. Daffodil Day raises €15,355 between the flower sales and the Lalor Centre Coffee morning. Baltinglass Library holds an Easter Hunt and Storytime in Tearmann Garden. Wicklow County Council apply for additional funding of €1.1 million to cover extra works for Baltinglass under the Rural Regeneration and Development Fund (RRDF).
April
Kieran Burke launches his campaign to become a Councillor ahead of the June 7 local elections. Lidl Ireland appeals to An Bord Pleanala following Wicklow Co Co decision to refuse planning permission for a new store in Baltinglass. Baltinglass GAA Club holds an Easter Family Day and Egg hunt on Easter Monday called Lá na gClub. Rural Revival hold an Information Day about fostering, in association with Tusla. Baltinglass Tidy Towns recommence their weekly clean-ups. Wicklow Minister Simon Harris becomes Taoiseach of Fine Gael on April 8 following the resignation of Leo Varadkar. Baltinglass Fairtrade and Baltinglass Hope for Humanity team up to hold a daytime vigil ‘Solidarity Sunday’ in very difficult weather conditions to show solidarity with the people of Gaza. Bia Blasta offer to support their previous employee Kelsey Kirby with her racing ambitions. Wicklow Local Sports Partnership leads a weekly walk and stretch for women, starting at Fatima Hall for 6-weeks. Thomas Whittle from Stratford-on-Slaney passes away. Baltinglass Golf Club celebrate Mark Doogue’s win of the Pat Ruddy Perpetual Trophy in Sligo. Erin and Stephen close Hangry for Hotdogs fastfood van in the square for the last time. Baltinglass GAA holds a 24-hour kickathon in aid of Scoil Naomh Iósaf and the GAA Juveniles, raising €4.2k. The Respond’s Rathcoran housing development in Baltinglass is recognised by the Chartered Institute of Housing with an Award for Excellence in Health and Wellbeing. The former Stratford Arms pub is to be converted into five one-bedroom apartments. Kiltegan hold a Variety Show in St. Tegan’s Hall. Rev Máirt Hanley organises a rescheduled walk as part of a pilot Ministry project developing the idea of a Slí Lorcán Ó Tuathail, going from Mullaghreelan Wood, through Baltinglass to join up with St Kevin’s way. 50 hikers from Scoil Chonglais raise €2,500 for their school with a sponsored walk to the top of Lugnaquilla. Baltinglass Kayak Club start their weekly sessions at the Weir. Mairead Kelly posts a new map of her Audio Tour of the Hillforts on her website irelandshillfortcapital.com created by Graphic Designer Santiago from deercún. Scoil Chonglais students hold a fundraising Car Wash day at O’Reilly’s Service Station to go towards enhancing the school life for all students in Scoil Chonglais. They raise €1,450. Vinny Gethings organises a music and storytelling session for the Lalor Centre and for Baltinglass Hospital, funded by Creative Places Baltinglass. William Brien from Baltinglass is a member of the AFL team, The Wandsworth Demons, who win the 2024 AFL Europe Champions League. Local musicians Taylor Hase, Kendal Moody and Cormac Doyle perform in Stratford Lodge as part of the ‘Sitting Room Sessions’ organised by Mark ‘Cappy’ Caplice and funded by Creative Places Baltinglass. Stephen Donnelly visits the Baltinglass Day Care Centre Committee in Baltinglass and announces funding of €300,000 for new facilities for Baltinglass Hospital.
May
The community is shocked by the tragic death of 15-year old Molly Dempsey. Mark Caplice and Leslie Dowdall ‘Both Sides Now’ tours the country. Turning Heads beauty salon opens in Baltinglass. Knockananna hold their First Car Boot sale of the season. The annual Country Music Show in aid of Baltinglass Hospital, Patient Comfort Fund takes place in the Glen Lounge The Baltinglass Rathvilly Macra hold a Batshit Bingo night in Inisfáil, Germaines in aid of Make the Moove supporting mental health in rural Ireland. Active Retired host an Afternoon Tea Dance funded by Creative Places Baltinglass to mark the start of Wicklow’s Bealtaine Festival activities. Darkness into Light takes place on May 11 with over 400 people taking part. Craft workshops are on-going in Baltinglass Library with Olha Fil. An Exhibition takes place in Baltinglass Library ‘Legendary Landscapes: Hidden Stories of the Wicklow Mountains’. The Scoil Chonglais annual Bake Sale is held and raises a massive €1,900. Baltinglass Credit Union celebrate their 50th anniversary by giving away cash prizes to members who register. May marked the 25th anniversary of the arrival of refugees from Kosovo. The launch of the GSMC Mini-stages rally takes place in Germaines. The Talbotstown Parent’s association hosted the annual Run for Lucy with 100 walkers and raised €1,600 for the school and the Irish Cancer Society. A Variety Show in St. Joseph’s church features a host of artists and raises €5,200 to be divided between the Lalor Centre and towards the refurbishment of the church.
Baltinglass Tidy Towns receives funding towards a ‘Ukrainian Hub’ at the Local Enhancement Awards run by Wicklow County Council. Bernie Doyle, John Kehoe and Eddie Lawrence from Baltinglass Kiltegan Bowling Club win the Kildare West Wicklow Mixed Trebles Championship in Rathcoffey. Baltinglass Palestine Solidarity group mark the Irish Government’s official recognition of the State of Palestine with a vigil at McAllister. Students of Scoil Chonglais Emma Langrill, Roisin Woulfe and Grace Gordon are recognised for their contributions as female cycling ambassadors at the #andshecycles awards ceremony in Dublin.
June
Polling Day for Local Elections takes place on June 7. Gerry O’Neill is elected on the 1st count, Edward Timmins on the 2nd Count, then Avril Cronin (FG), Patsy Glennon (FF), Jason Mulhall (independent) and Peter Stapleton (FG). Celia O’Connor from Irongrange celebrates her 100th birthday. Baltinglass Golf Club and Baltinglass Tidy Towns hold the annual sponsored walk in the golf club. Cruinniú na nÓg the national day of creativity for young people, takes place in Tearmann Community Garden with workshops in song-writing and bracelet-making, origami, dream-catchers, earth mobiles and wind chimes. Bigstone Community Centre committee celebrates The community hall’s 40th anniversary with Alan Dukes in attendance, who originally opened the centre 40 year before. Andrew Pender is ordained Deacon in St. Mary’s Church. The transformative ground and planting works at Chapel Hill is complete, a project undertaken by Baltinglass Tidy Towns with much of the ground works done by the local Council crew. Baltinglass Sings hold their summer concert in Germaines. Tynock national school begins raising money to help them celebrate their 75th anniversary this year. ACCA student and Baltinglass native, Regina Carpenter finishes amongst the world’s best in her accountancy exams. Tirlan invite famers to come along to an Open Farm Walk on Donal Kavanagh’s farm in Carrigeen, Baltinglass. County Wicklow Library Service is awarded Library of Sanctuary at a ceremony in County Buildings.
